fields.description:
Fisheye and Crucible 4.6.x use embedded-crowd library version 2.9.5-7fb674b. This is a custom build with performance tweaks for nested groups.

As of Sep'18, the latest version is 3.3.0. There are over 160 bug fixes in +Crowd+  since 2.9.5 up to 3.3.0 (note the embedded crowd is a library, so it is affected by only a subset of issues listed below):

[fixVersion = 1.9.6 .. 3.3.0|https://jira.atlassian.com/issues/?jql=project%20%3D%20CWD%20AND%20resolution%20%3D%20Fixed%20AND%20fixVersion%20in%20(3.2.4%2C%203.3.0%2C%203.3.1%2C%202.10.1%2C%202.10.2%2C%202.10.3%2C%202.11.0%2C%202.11.1%2C%202.11.2%2C%202.12.0%2C%202.9.7%2C%203.0.0%2C%203.0.1%2C%203.0.2%2C%203.0.3%2C%203.1.0%2C%203.1.1%2C%203.1.2%2C%203.1.3%2C%203.1.4%2C%203.1.5%2C%203.2.0%2C%203.2.1%2C%203.2.2%2C%203.2.3%2C%203.2.5)]

Few of them worth noticing:
 * CWD-3255 - do not unnecessarily fallback to full synchronisation
fields.summary: Upgrade embedded Crowd to 3.3.0 or later

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

With an application link to Jira, the regex to identify issues keys pick up anything that matches including other external system keys. Example: *{{ABC-1234-123456}}*

h3. Suggested Solution

Fisheye allows you to have [Linkers|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/linkers-298976904.html] if you are not connected via application link. This can be defined per project.

As an admin, I would like to continue to use the Jira Application Link, but I would also like the ability to exclude specific repositories from the regex matching.
 
h3. Workaround

Users can add an escape character "\" to break regex matching:
{code:borderStyle=solid}
ABC\-1234-123456 
{code}
fields.summary: Add ability to disable Jira Regex per repository

fields.description:
Reported by one customer: if there are few repositories containing the same issue key and one repository is not accessible, then Jira dev panel does not show any commits. It shall show commits from the repositories for which user has read access.


*Unable to reproduce*. 

Steps performed:

Two Git repositories - repo1 and repo2 both containing commits with 'MARS-1' issue key.
Fisheye and Jira connected via application link with "OAuth (impersonation)"
Two users in both applications: Admin and Alice. 
Admin has read/admin access to both 'repo1' and 'repo2' in Fisheye.
Alice has read access only to 'repo2' in Fisheye.
After indexing the repos, log into Jira as Admin and Alice and click 'X commits' link in the Development panel. 

I found that the information shown is correct for both Admin and Alice...
fields.summary: Jira Development panel shows no commits if user has no access to some repository

fields.description:
For the [Supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/supported-platforms-298976955.html] page, under the *Mercurial* supported platforms, right column, we need to add a recommendation/warning not to use non-ascii characters in filenames and paths, if using Mercurial on Windows, with a link to the following: [FE\-7094: Add support for different file paths encoding for Mercurial|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-7094].

Using non ASCII characters in that configuration will not allow the repositories to index.
fields.summary: Fisheye Supported Platforms documentation should have a warning about using Mercurial on Windows with non ASCII characters in path

fields.description:
Perforce can have problems with non UTF-8 compatible encodings used in file paths. Simple solution was provided as a result of this FE-6909 bug.

It is possible, that file paths are encoded in different encoding than content of the files. Current behaviour allow to set one for whole repository.

Encoding have to be set according to the file paths, otherwise Fisheye will be unable to index repository. In result content of the files can be not rendered properly:

!bad-encoding.PNG|width=607,height=85!

Provide solution to choose different encoding only for file paths. It will allow to index non UTF-8 file names properly, but also render file content correctly.
fields.summary: Support separate encoding settings for file content and file paths in Perforce

fields.description:
*Mercurial has no native support for different encoding of file paths*. It can determine encoding of content, but file paths are not supported.
{quote}Decoding ambiguities apply to file contents, as well as file names in the bytes-based manifest. This spec applies to the former only and does not address manifest parsing. ([Tracking File Encoding in Mercurial|https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/Tracking%20File%20Encoding?highlight=%28windows%29%7C%28charset%29%7C%28encoding%29])
{quote}
File paths are stored in binary form, thus cannot determine encoding properly. Most modern systems use UTF-8, except for Windows which use their own, incompatible with the UTF standard code pages.

We strongly encourage our customers, to *not use non-ASCII* letters in file paths, because not only Fisheye will be unable to index repository but also it *breaks compatibility* between different systems.
h3. More details about possible configurations

If Mercurial repository doesn't contain non ASCII characters in file paths, any configuration should work correctly.

Otherwise it can cause Fisheye to be unable to index repository. Crucial piece are *committers* here. If they use Windows as their target platform, non UTF-8 characters can be committed causing problems.

Possible platforms:
 * Fisheye on Windows - cannot index non ASCII file paths
 * Fisheye on Linux - can index repository, if file paths are encoded in UTF-8

h3. Workarounds
h4. I'm not affected but I want to be sure it will not happen in future
 * *encourage your team to use only ASCII characters in file paths.*
 * ensure all committers use OS with UTF-8 set as default encoding (modern UNIX related systems - Mac OS, Linux)

h4. I'm affected, what can I do now?
 * affected paths could be added to {{excluded paths}}. It will require repository reindex; after reindex excluded files will be not available in Fisheye
 * repository can be converted using [hg convert|https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/ConvertExtension#A–filemap]; it provides ability to rename files, so non ASCII characters can be removed
*NOTE! It creates a new repository, commit hashes and other internal elements will be different, it may break links in other tools. For example, existing Crucible code reviews will point to non-existing commit hashes.*

h3. Proposed solution

Provide ability to choose file path encoding for Mercurial repositories, so Fisheye will be able to properly decode and encode paths. 

Note: if the option would be set at the repository level, then it requires that all Mercurial clients committing non-ascii paths has to be configured to use the same path encoding - for example all committers running Windows with the same codepage.
fields.summary: Add support for different file paths encoding for Mercurial

fields.description:
h3. Problem

Fisheye and Crucible has a number of managers and services available. They can be imported by plugins, however their interfaces are located in the main fisheye.jar, not in the fisheye-api.jar. 

As a consequence:
 * they're not documented in JavaDocs and
 * it's necessary to add a dependency on the core JAR instead of the API JAR only.

h3. Expected fix

Move all non-internal interfaces of managers and services to Fisheye API.
h3. Workaround

Add fisheye.jar as dependency.
fields.summary: Expose Fisheye and Crucible services in Java API

fields.description:
h4. Summary


As of Fisheye/Crucible version 4.4.1 we allow smart commits against Jira project with customized issue keys, and not just the default ABC-123 (Letters, hyphen, number).
See implementation in [FE\-4155: Support Smart Commits with customized JIRA keys (fixed in FishEye 4.4.1)|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-4155]

The following documentation needs to be updated to reflect this fact for Fisheye/Crucible versions > 4.4.1

[Using Smart Commits \- Get Smart Commits working|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/using-smart-commits-298976812.html#UsingSmartCommits-GetSmartCommitsworking]

h4. Suggested solution
Add a disclaimer before or after the following bullet point -- that this is valid only for Fisheye versions < 4.4.1
"Smart Commits only support the default Jira Software issue key format (that is, two or more uppercase letters, followed by a hyphen and the issue number, for example BAM-123)."
fields.summary: Update documentation on smart commits to reflect support for customized Jira issue keys

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When stopping Fisheye and Crucible, a heap is created that is the size set in $FISHEYE_OPTS.  When using G1GC and large Fisheye instance, this causes a heap to be created to the Xsx causing 

h3. Workaround
Edit fisheyectl.sh with the following changes.  Note that only start uses {{$FISHEYE_OPTS}}.

{code}
diff --git a/fisheyectl.sh.orig b/fisheyectl.sh
index 53ed4af..4a2a34f 100755
--- a/fisheyectl.sh.orig
+++ b/fisheyectl.sh
@@ -48,14 +48,15 @@ fi

 FISHEYE_OPTS=`$JAVACMD -cp $FISHEYE_HOME/fisheyeboot.jar com.cenqua.fisheye.boot.OptsSetter`

-FISHEYE_CMD="$JAVACMD $FISHEYE_OPTS -Dfisheye.library.path=$FISHEYE_LIBRARY_PATH -Dfisheye.inst=$FISHEYE_INST -Djava.awt.headless=true -Djava.endorsed.dirs=$FISHEYE_HOME/lib/endorsed -jar $FISHEYE_HOME/fisheyeboot.jar"
 if [ "$1" = "start" ] ; then
+  FISHEYE_CMD="$JAVACMD $FISHEYE_OPTS -Dfisheye.library.path=$FISHEYE_LIBRARY_PATH -Dfisheye.inst=$FISHEYE_INST -Djava.awt.headless=true -Djava.endorsed.dirs=$FISHEYE_HOME/lib/endorsed -jar $FISHEYE_HOME/fisheyeboot.jar"
   cd $FISHEYE_INST
   mkdir -p $FISHEYE_INST/var/log
   CMD="$FISHEYE_CMD $@ $FISHEYE_ARGS"
   echo "Starting FishEye/Crucible... Output redirected to $FISHEYE_INST/var/log/fisheye.out"
   nohup sh -c "exec $CMD" >> $FISHEYE_INST/var/log/fisheye.out 2>&1 &
 else
+  FISHEYE_CMD="$JAVACMD -Dfisheye.library.path=$FISHEYE_LIBRARY_PATH -Dfisheye.inst=$FISHEYE_INST -Djava.awt.headless=true -Djava.endorsed.dirs=$FISHEYE_HOME/lib/endorsed -jar $FISHEYE_HOME/fisheyeboot.jar"
   exec $FISHEYE_CMD $@ $FISHEYE_ARGS
 fi
{code}
fields.summary: Stopping Fisheye launches second heap to size of Xms

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
We recommend at [Best practices for Fisheye configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/best-practices-for-fisheye-configuration-298976952.html] and at [Best practices Subversion integration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/best-practices-subversion-integration-336170251.html] the usage of {{svnsync}} in order to mirror remote Subversion repositories currently accessible via http/s into the machine hosting Fisheye, so that Fisheye can index these repositories using file protocol. 

However, the [svnsync documentation|http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/subversion/trunk/notes/svnsync.txt] linked in both of these documents only contains instructions for Linux / Mac users, so customers that run Fisheye in Windows environments might find it hard to implement that suggestion.

Therefore, I have created an article explaining [how to use {{svnsync}} in Windows environments|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/how-to-use-svnsync-in-windows-environments-955186346.html].

h3. Suggested Solution

Add a link to [How to use svnsync in Windows environments|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/how-to-use-svnsync-in-windows-environments-955186346.html] in both documents:
* [Best practices for Fisheye configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/best-practices-for-fisheye-configuration-298976952.html]
* [Best practices Subversion integration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/best-practices-subversion-integration-336170251.html]
fields.summary: Update Best Practices documents

fields.description: Several resources in Atlassian Fisheye and Crucible before version 4.6.0 allow remote attackers to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in linked issue keys.
fields.summary: Several resources were vulnerable to XSS - CVE-2018-13392

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Clicking in any of the links highlighted in the image below results in Page not Found error:
!screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Make sure to be running Fisheye/Crucible 4.6.0
# Click the links

h3. Actual Results
* Fisheye *Help* link is redirecting to https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE046/FishEye+Documentation+Home
* Fisheye *What's New* is redirecting to https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE046/FishEye+Releases
* Crucible *Help* link is redirecting to https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE046/Crucible+Documentation+Home
* Crucible *What's New* is redirecting to https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE046/Crucible+Releases. 

h3. Expected Results
* Fisheye *Help* link should redirect to https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye
* Fisheye *What's New* link should redirect to https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/fisheye-releases-298976966.html
* Crucible *Help* link should redirect to https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible
* Crucible *What's New* link should redirect to https://confluence.atlassian.com/crucible/crucible-releases-298977378.html

h3. Workaround
There are no workarounds thus far, other than using the correct links mentioned in *Expected Results*.
fields.summary: Fisheye/Crucible help menu redirects to wrong resources

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
It appears Fisheye does not handle git subtree correctly. Fisheye doesn't really exclude even if the the local exclude path specified.

h3. Suggested Solution
Fisheye recognizes git subtree pull squash commits, and adds the subtree path in when testing Include/Exclude paths

h3. Workaround
No workaround
fields.summary: Support git subtree in Fisheye

fields.description: The version of the bundled Atlassian Universal Plugin Manager plugin had a XML External Entity vulnerability that allowed remote attackers with system administrator privileges to read files, make network requests and perform a denial of service attack via an XML External Entity vulnerability in the parsing of atlassian plugin xml files in an uploaded JAR. See https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/UPM-5964 for more details.
fields.summary: The bundled Atlassian Universal Plugin Manager plugin had a XXE issue - CVE-2018-20233

fields.description:
Subversion 1.10 has been released on 2018-04-13. It brings the following changes:
 * [https://subversion.apache.org/docs/release-notes/1.10]

 

Excerpts from the release notes:

_Subversion 1.10 uses the same working copy format as Subversion 1.8 and 1.9._

_The default filesystem format is now version 8, introduced in 1.10. The format bump is required to allow using LZ4 compression for the data that is stored on the disk._ 

 

Ensure that Fisheye works with this version using both:
 * SVNKit java library - TMateSoft released [SVNKit 1.10|https://svnkit.com/download.php] in December, 2018 (y)
 * native client library

h3. Note

As per SVNkit web page:

"SVNKit 1.10.0 is compatible both with Subversion 1.10, 1.9, 1.8 and Subversion 1.7 working copy formats."

Fisheye currently supports Subversion 1.5, 1.6, 1.7, 1.8, 1.9. Check which repository formats are supported as it may mean that we will have to drop support for 1.5 & 1.6.
fields.summary: Support Subversion 1.10 LTS

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Fisheye supports both {{Latin1_General_CS_AS}} and {{SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CS_AS}} collations.

The [MS SQL Server documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/migrating-to-sql-server-298976839.html] for Fisheye only mentions {{Latin1_General_CS_AS}} as a supported collation.


h3. Suggested Solution
Update the documentation to mention that both collations are supported:
- {{Latin1_General_CS_AS}}
- {{SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CS_AS}}

This applies to all Fisheye/Crucible versions supported (4.2 and higher).
fields.summary: Update MS SQL Server collation documentation

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Global Permission fails to be set to group name containing comma.

h3. Environment
* Syncing users and groups from Crowd 3.1.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a group with comma character, such as {{"dl-TEST-NAME, PROJECT"}}, in Crowd, then associate users with it, and make sure that a Fisheye application is allowing that group to authenticate.
# Add Crowd as User Directory in Fisheye
# Note that this group gets synced correctly:
!Screen Shot 2018-07-05 at 18.12.33.png|thumbnail!
# Click the group name and see that it contains the correct users:
!Screen Shot 2018-07-05 at 18.12.41.png|thumbnail!
# Go to Global Permissions, click the search field and note that the group is listed correctly:
!Screen Shot 2018-07-05 at 18.05.56.png|thumbnail!
# Click the group name and note that it is added to the search box as a single group:
!Screen Shot 2018-07-05 at 18.06.09.png|thumbnail!
# Now click the Add button and see that the page refreshes and the group name is split in two, in the comma character, and that there's an error message saying {{Cannot add *dl-test-name", "project*}}:
!Screen Shot 2018-07-05 at 18.06.18.png|thumbnail!

Global Permission should allow using comma character in the group name.

* Do not use group names with comma.

fields.description:
h3. Problem

It's possible to download source code JAR of the Jira Fisheye Plugin, but it's not possible to download the entire source repository. Having access to the repository would make compilation of the plugin much easier.
h3. Workaround

Download source JAR from [https://packages.atlassian.com/maven-public-legacy/com/atlassian/jira/plugins/jira-fisheye-plugin/]
fields.summary: Grant access to source code repository for jira-fisheye-plugin

fields.description:
h2. Problem statement

The following documentation page [https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/connecting-to-an-existing-ldap-directory-812223034.html] includes links to pages that are not public. As an example, the link "How to write LDAP search filters" under heading *Option - Use LDAP filters to restrict the number of users and groups that are synchronized*, redirects to an internal Confluence page, as opposed to the public URL [https://confluence.atlassian.com/kb/how-to-write-ldap-search-filters-792496933.html].

Similarly, some items on the right side menu under *Related Content*, such as the link "Delegating authentication to an LDAP directory" also redirect to non public-facing URLs.
h2. Proposed Solution

Replace the links with public-facing URLs.
fields.summary: Documentation revision on connecting to LDAP directory

fields.description:
The analytics plugin 5.4.4 requires joda-time 2.2 or later. Fisheye/Crucible bundles joda-time 2.0. 

As a result analytics data can't be uploaded to S3 bucket. 

{noformat}
[Message] Unable to parse last modified date: Fri, 11 Sep 2015 01:16:54 GMT
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Joda-time 2.2 or later version is required, but found version: 2.0
	at com.amazonaws.util.DateUtils.handleException(DateUtils.java:146) [analytics-client-5.4.4_1521644430000.jar:?]
	at com.amazonaws.util.DateUtils.parseRFC822Date(DateUtils.java:194) [analytics-client-5.4.4_1521644430000.jar:?]
	at com.amazonaws.services.s3.internal.ServiceUtils.parseRfc822Date(ServiceUtils.java:72) [analytics-client-5.4.4_1521644430000.jar:?]
	at com.amazonaws.services.s3.internal.AbstractS3ResponseHandler.populateObjectMetadata(AbstractS3ResponseHandler.java:115) [analytics-client-5.4.4_1521644430000.jar:?]
	at com.amazonaws.services.s3.internal.S3ObjectResponseHandler.handle(S3ObjectResponseHandler.java:52) [analytics-client-5.4.4_1521644430000.jar:?]
	at com.amazonaws.services.s3.internal.S3ObjectResponseHandler.handle(S3ObjectResponseHandler.java:30) [analytics-client-5.4.4_1521644430000.jar:?]
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.handleResponse(AmazonHttpClient.java:828) [analytics-client-5.4.4_1521644430000.jar:?]
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.executeHelper(AmazonHttpClient.java:481) [analytics-client-5.4.4_1521644430000.jar:?]
...

Probably we'll need to fix it on all versions from *4.2* up. 

Note that 4.1 EOL Date is Jun 28, 2018.

Note: as per analytics-project/pom.xml, the joda-time version used shall be 2.3.
fields.summary: Analytics plugin requires joda-time 2.2 or later

fields.description:
SVNKit contains bug related to new SVN filesystem format (introduced in SVN 1.9).
h3. Prerequisites
 * Any supported version of Fisheye
 * connected SVN repository that uses filesystem format *FSFS in version 7*
 ** check if repository is vulnerable by running this command on *SVN server*
{code:java}
cat <path to repository>/db/format{code}
 ** if repository is vulnerable, output will look similar to:
{code:java}
7
layout sharded 1000
addressing logical
{code}

h3. Symptoms
 * {{IllegalArgumentException}} appears in log with similar stacktrace:

{code:java}
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
	at sun.nio.ch.FileChannelImpl.position(FileChannelImpl.java:278) [?:1.8.0_60]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSFile.fill(FSFile.java:462) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSFile.read(FSFile.java:367) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSFile.readLine(FSFile.java:147) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSRoot.readChange(FSRoot.java:311) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSRoot.fetchAllChanges(FSRoot.java:273) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSRevisionRoot.getChangedPaths(FSRevisionRoot.java:52) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSRoot.detectChanged(FSRoot.java:293) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSLog.fillLogEntry(FSLog.java:343) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSLog.sendLog(FSLog.java:290) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSLog.runLog(FSLog.java:162) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.fs.FSRepository.logImpl(FSRepository.java:383) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.io.SVNRepository.log(SVNRepository.java:1038) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.remote.SvnRemoteLog.run(SvnRemoteLog.java:181) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.remote.SvnRemoteLog.run(SvnRemoteLog.java:35) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc2.SvnOperationRunner.run(SvnOperationRunner.java:21) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.wc2.SvnOperationFactory.run(SvnOperationFactory.java:1235) [svnkit-1.9.0-r10609-atlassian-hosted.jar:?]
{code}
 * Fisheye pauses index/reindex of repository

h3. Possible fix

Upgrade SVNKit to the version 1.9 or higher should resolve this bug. (Fix in SVNKit was introduced in version 1.9.0)
h3. Workaround

Native SVN client should be used instead of bundled SVNKit. Instruction [how to switch to native client|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/native-subversion-client-298976879.html].
fields.summary: SVNKit fails to index SVN 1.9+ repository

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When editing an existing application link details and hitting save, the UI and logs generate an error.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an Application Link between Fisheye/Crucible and Bitbucket Server without the option “The servers have the same set of users and usernames.”
# Edit the Application Link in Fisheye/Crucible
# Attempt to perform any changes (or even no changes at all) in the application link (such as changing the authentication from OAuth to OAuth (Impersonation) or vice versa, or editing the application link name)
# Save changes


h3. Expected Results
The new setting is successfully changed.

h3. Actual Results
The setting couldn't be saved and the below exception is thrown in the atlassian-fisheye-DATE.log file:

org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: could not execute statement

fields.description:
Summary -
Commits coming from Fisheye into Jira Activity stream will have a date that is non 24 hour format.
Customers would like the option to change this formatting to 24 hours.

Related Fisheye code that sends fixed 12hour format -
{code:title=Fisheye code}
final UserProfile userProfile = userManager.getRemoteUser();
        gitRepo.setDescription(
                String.format(
                        "Added by %s on %s",
                        userProfile != null ? userProfile.getUsername() : "<unknown>",
                        new SimpleDateFormat("EEE dd MMM yyy, hh:mm a").format(new Date())));
{code} 
This comes into Jira Activity stream as a hyperlink -
{code:title=http dump logs from Jira shows}
<activity:target>
	<id>urn:uuid:xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx-xxxxcc0cc</id>
	<title type="text">Added by username on Monday 28 May 2018, 10:30 AM</title>
	<link rel="alternate" href="http://fisheyeurl/fisheye/changelog/ansible" />
	<activity:object-type>http://streams.atlassian.com/syndication/types/repository</activity:object-type>
</activity:target>
{code}

This is something Jira will not be able to convert into 24 hour formatting from the settings in Jira as it is a title to a link.

See screenshot of how it comes into Jira activity stream -
 !fisheye stream.jpg|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Fisheye streams to Jira with non-24hour dates

fields.description:
h3.Problem
- Currently when the licensed user count is exceeded, anyone who is logged into Fisheye/Crucible is presented with the warning page in this regard.

- Until the admin resolves the license count, other logged users are unable to continue their work and after the issue is resolved, all work in progress is lost.

h3.Suggested Resolution 
- It would be helpful if a less intrusive banner was implemented to warn the admin the license count has been exceeded.
- In addition, a 24hour grace period before stopping functionality would allow the admin a bit of time to either upgrade and/or remove users while also allowing other licensed users to continue their work
- At the very least, work in progress, namely reviews, should still be available so the user can continue their work after the license count issue is resolved
fields.summary: As a user it would be helpful if the "exceeded licensed user count" behavior was modified

fields.description:
User Mapping *per project* is extremely cumbersome, especially because adding a single user mapping is already cumbersome.

We have a slew of users that don't set up their GIT emails correct and instead of <user>@<domain> it becomes <user>@<host>.<domain>.  This obviously doesn't make.

Either make the User Mapping more user friendly or add a feature where you can generally rewrite or recognize emails base on a common domain suffix.
fields.summary: User Mappings

fields.description:
Fisheye provides ability to download binary files from repository. Download link is corrupted if file name contains special letters.
h3. Steps to reproduce:
 # Add binary file with the special letters in name (e.g. _file with (strange) #chars.exe_) to the repository
 # Add repository to the Fisheye
 # Open file page in the Fisheye
 # Click on _Download revision <revision hash>_ link

h3. Expected result:
 * file starts to downloading

h3. Actual result:
 * error page appears:
 !Screen Shot 2018-05-04 at 16.51.18.png|width=257,height=143!

h3. Cause

Fisheye does not replace html char codes properly, so it tries to find file with name _file%20with%20%28strange%29%20%23chars.exe_ instead of _file with (strange) #chars.exe_.

Problem occurs if path to file from the repository root contains non-standard chars.

 
h3. Workaround

Expected url can be created manually. Each occurrence of  _%25_ should be changed to _%_. 
h5. Example

Fisheye generates link to the file:
 *  _<url>/file%2520with%2520%2528strange%2529%2520%2523chars.exe_

Valid url should look like:
 * _<url>/file%20with%20%28strange%29%20%23chars.exe_
fields.summary: Cannot download binary file if name contains special characters

h3. Problem Definition
With the latest versions of Windows (e.g. Windows 10), using Wandisco will lead to the following error:
{noformat}
C:\Program Files (x86)\WANdisco\Subversion\libsvnjavahl-1.dll: Can't load IA 32-bit .dll on a AMD 64-bit platform
{noformat}

Because of this, Fisheye will not be able to index any SVN repository.

h3. Suggested Solution
Update the [Native support for SVN|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/native-support-for-svn-389780391.html] page to provide an updated list of compatible Native Clients on Windows.

In our test environments, SlikSVN allows Fisheye to connect successfully when using the Wandisco dll (see [Getting Native Subversion Client to work with FishEye on a Windows 64\-bit Machine|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/getting-native-subversion-client-to-work-with-fisheye-on-a-windows-64-bit-machine-765594168.html] for reference).
fields.summary: Update the documentation to clarify which Native clients can be used on a Windows server

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

FishEye/ Crucible does not currently support connecting to load-balanced AD servers.

Synchronising between AD servers is not supported. Microsoft Active Directory does not replicate the uSNChanged attribute across instances. For that reason, we do not support connecting to different AD servers for synchronisation.

Many companies have a single DNS entry (mydomain.mycompany.com) that points to a load balancer that directs traffic to one of many directory servers. (Or, some companies might use DNS round robin.) However, neither the use of DNS round robin nor use of an actual load balancer is supported by FishEye/ Crucible – both approaches to load balancing direct traffic to different servers, which would violate limitation #2 above.
 Currently, FishEye/ Crucible only supports connecting to a single directory server, not different (load-balanced) servers.

h3. Suggested Solution

Add support for load-balanced LDAP/AD. 

h3. Workaround 

Connect to a single LDAP server.
fields.summary: Support load-balanced LDAP/AD servers with FishEye/ Crucible

{noformat}
Error testing connection.
Error talking to repository: 
fatal: ssh variant 'simple' does not support setting port
at com.atlassian.fisheye.git.GitScmConfig.testConnection(GitScmConfig.java:120)
at com.cenqua.fisheye.RepositoryConfig.testConnection(RepositoryConfig.java:390)
at com.atlassian.fisheye.spi.admin.impl.DefaultRepositoryAdminService.testConnectionFor(DefaultRepositoryAdminService.java:964)

{noformat}
 
h3. Environment
 * Git 2.16.0 or higher and

fields.description:
Fisheye and Crucible did not correctly check if a configured Mercurial repository URI contained values that the Windows operating system may consider argument parameters. An attacker who has permission to add a repository in Fisheye or Crucible can execute code of their choice on systems that run a vulnerable version of Fisheye or Crucible on the Windows operating system.


*Affected versions:*
 * All versions of Fisheye and Crucible before 4.4.6 (the fixed version for 4.4.x) and from 4.5.0 before 4.5.3 (the fixed version for 4.5.x) are affected by this vulnerability.


*Fix:*
 * Fisheye version 4.5.3 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download].
 * Crucible version 4.5.3 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crucible/download].
 * Fisheye version 4.4.6 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download-archives].
 * Crucible version 4.4.6 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crucible/download-archives].

*Acknowledgements*
Atlassian would like to credit Zhang Tianqi @ Tophant for reporting this issue to us.


For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/aS5sO].
fields.summary: Argument injection through Mercurial repository uri handling on Windows - CVE-2018-5223

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When migrating to a new database, the migration fails because Fisheye tries to migrate all tables starting with {{cwd_}} and {{cru_}}.

In case a non expected tables exists in the schema (e.g. due to a previous failed migration), the migration fails with a database error.
For example, when using an Oracle database the following error is reported:
{noformat}
ORA-00942: table or view does not exist
{noformat}

Migrating to a new database is commonly used in the attempt to move Fisheye to a database containing only and all the expected structure.

h3. Suggested Solution

1. Database migration should migrate only the expected tables to the new database.
2. Backup should dump only the expected tables to the new database.
3. Add system startup health check - do not start Fisheye/Crucible if unknown cru_* and cwd_* tables are detected and print warning about it.
4. Extend our upgrade guide - add section how not to make db restore to avoid this corruption.

h3. Workaround
(!) Direct database modifications are not supported. 
Reach out to the Atlassian Support prior to modifying the database for further details on how to proceed if you are facing this issue.
fields.summary: As an admin, I would like only the data from the expected tables to be migrated to a new database

fields.description:
h2. Problem

Fisheye/Crucible uses an external directory, in which a user is being automatically added to a certain group upon successful login. That group is used to grant 'Fisheye' and/or 'Crucible' access (Administration > Global permissions). User is unable to log in. 

h2. Steps to reproduce

* Set up Crowd as follows
** Add Fisheye/Crucible application
** Add 'Crowd internal' directory
*** Add 'fisheye-crucible-users' group
*** Add 'user1' user, do not assign to the group above
** On the 'Options' tab pick the 'fisheye-crucible-users' group to be automatically added to

* Set up Fisheye/Crucible as follows
** Add 'Atlassian Crowd' directory
** On the 'Groups' page remove 'fisheye-users' and 'crucible-users' groups; you shall see the 'fisheye-crucible-users' listed
** On the 'Global Permissions' page grant 'fisheye-crucible-users' group the 'Fisheye & Crucible access' 
** On the 'Users' page you shall see 'user1'; it has no group assigned and the 'no access' red label

* Log out and log in as 'user1'
** Login fails (!)

* Log in as administrator
** On the 'Users' page you shall see that 'user1' is now a member of 'fisheye-crucible-users' group, 
** but the label still shows 'no access' (!)


h2. Cause

A global permission cache is not refreshed after user is automatically added to a group in an external directory and that group grants Fisheye and/or Crucible global permissions. 

h2. Workaround

The global permission cache expires after 24 hours unless some action triggers invalidation.

Trigger invalidation of the global permission cache by one of the following:
 * add a new user in Fisheye/Crucible (you can use an 'internal directory' if available)
 * change any user's group membership
 * restart Fisheye / Crucible
fields.summary: User's permissions are not refreshed if the user is being automatically added to a group in external directory and this group controls global permissions

fields.description:
The source browse resource in Atlassian FishEye and Crucible before version 4.5.1 and 4.6.0 allows allows remote attackers that have write access to an indexed repository to inject arbitrary HTML or JavaScript via a cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in via a specially crafted repository branch name when trying to display deleted files of the branch.


h3. Affected versions
 * Older than 4.5.1

h3. Fixed versions
 * 4.5.1 and higher
 * 4.6.0 and higher
fields.summary: XSS in the source browser resource through malicious branch names - CVE-2017-18034

fields.description:
It was possible for double OGNL evaluation in certain redirect action and in WebWork URL and Anchor tags in JSP files to occur. An attacker who can access the web interface of Fisheye or Crucible or who hosts a website that a user who can access the web interface of Fisheye or Crucible visits, is able to exploit this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that run a vulnerable version of Fisheye or Crucible.

*Affected versions:*
 * All versions of Fisheye and Crucible before 4.4.5 (the fixed version for 4.4.x) and from 4.5.0 before 4.5.2 (the fixed version for 4.5.x) are affected by this vulnerability.

*Fix:*
 * Fisheye version 4.5.2 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download].
 * Crucible version 4.5.2 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/crucible/download].
 * Fisheye version 4.4.5 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download-archives].
 * Crucible version 4.4.5 is available to download from [https://www.atlassian.com/software/fisheye/download-archives].

For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/iPQyO].
fields.summary: Remote code execution through OGNL double evaluation - CVE-2017-16861

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Once a backup has been started, it is not possible to stop it. In case a backup runs for a long time, the access to Fisheye cannot be restored.

This applies to all backup options:
- started from the user interface
- scheduled backup
- started using the {{./fisheyectl.sh backup}} option

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a cancel mechanism for stopping the backup.
For example, Bitbucket Server, provide a cancel token that can be entered in the user interface to stop the backup ([Using the Bitbucket Server Backup Client \- Canceling the client backup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-the-bitbucket-server-backup-client-776640064.html#UsingtheBitbucketServerBackupClient-Cancelingtheclientbackup]).

h3. Workaround
Restarting Fisheye will stop the backup from running.
fields.summary: As an admin, I would like to cancel a backup to restore access to Fisheye

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After upgrading (or installing) Fisheye *4.5.1* and running it for some time, Fisheye becomes not responsive and a restart is required.

This is caused by the unavailability of database connections in the pool.

h3. Expected Results
Fisheye is always responsive.

h3. Actual Results
There are no errors in the logs, the logs only contain references to repository indexes without any obvious slow down.

Thread dumps will show a significant amount of thread waiting to get a connection from the pool:
{noformat}"qtp1663844181-121926" #121926 prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007fcce8135000 nid=0x146b waiting on condition [0x00007fcc795fd000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: TIMED_WAITING (parking)
        at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
        - parking to wait for  <0x0000000646b6d418> (a com.jolbox.bonecp.BoundedLinkedTransferQueue)
        at java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.parkNanos(LockSupport.java:215)
        at jsr166y.LinkedTransferQueue.awaitMatch(LinkedTransferQueue.java:691)
        at jsr166y.LinkedTransferQueue.xfer(LinkedTransferQueue.java:600)
        at jsr166y.LinkedTransferQueue.poll(LinkedTransferQueue.java:1068)
        at com.jolbox.bonecp.BoundedLinkedTransferQueue.poll(BoundedLinkedTransferQueue.java:78)
        at com.jolbox.bonecp.BoneCP.getConnection(BoneCP.java:500)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.trackingstatements.HibernateBonceCPConnectionProvider.getConnection(HibernateBonceCPConnectionProvider.java:171)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.trackingstatements.TrackingStatementsConnectionProvider.getConnection(TrackingStatementsConnectionProvider.java:26)
        at org.hibernate.internal.AbstractSessionImpl$NonContextualJdbcConnectionAccess.obtainConnection(AbstractSessionImpl.java:301)
        at org.hibernate.engine.jdbc.internal.LogicalConnectionImpl.obtainConnection(LogicalConnectionImpl.java:214)
        at org.hibernate.engine.jdbc.internal.LogicalConnectionImpl.getConnection(LogicalConnectionImpl.java:157)
        at org.hibernate.engine.transaction.internal.jdbc.JdbcTransaction.doBegin(JdbcTransaction.java:67)
        at org.hibernate.engine.transaction.spi.AbstractTransactionImpl.begin(AbstractTransactionImpl.java:160)
        at org.hibernate.internal.SessionImpl.beginTransaction(SessionImpl.java:1351)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.SessionState.beginTx(SessionState.java:60)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.HibernateUtil.beginTransaction(HibernateUtil.java:372)
{noformat}


h3.Workaround
Not available
fields.summary: BoneCP connections are not returned to the pool

fields.summary: Correct Links in FishEye/Crucible Help Panel

fields.description:
Right now from what I can tell any mention of a Jira bug / id is seen as a commit in the development panel within Jira.

 

For instance, if you have a description of: "I see XYZ-123 causes this problem in XYZ-456" and you are looking in Jira at XYZ-123's development panel commit section you will see a commit associated with this bug just because it is mentioned elsewhere. Is it possible to have a config change that would allow you to search based on a key word.

 

Again for instance with the same above example, if I preface BUG:XYZ-123 then I only show a commit when I see anything beginning with "BUG:" So in the above case XYZ-456 would not be considered a commit.

 

This would help us greatly as we get false positives some times that leads to confusion.

 

Thanks in advance.
fields.summary: In the commits section for Jira's Development Panel allow for a way to do customized search in terms of what is reported as a commit

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the installer always considers that a new installation is being performed. It does not offer an option for upgrading an existing instance, such as Jira and Bitbucket Server installers do.

h3. Suggested Solution
The installer should show two options in its first step:
* one for installing a fresh instance
* the other for upgrading an existing instance

If the option for upgrading an existing instance is chosen, the installer should:
* uninstall the previous instance
* uninstall its Windows / Linux service (if applicable) or update it because the installation directory might change
* in one of the next steps it should ask the user to select the directory used as {{FISHEYE_INST}} by the old instance if it cannot be detected automatically from environment variables.

h3. Workaround
There are no known workarounds.
fields.summary: Installer should offer option for upgrading an existing instance

fields.description:

fields.summary: Add option to set default charset encoding for file content for Mercurial

fields.description:
h3. Environment
JIRA 7.4.1-latest
Fisheye 4.4.1-latest



h3. Steps to Reproduce
Link JIRA issue to Fisheye repository commit or Crucible review. Confirm it appears in the issue's Development Panel.
Delete the Fisheye repository or review.
View the linked issue page in JIRA and observe the Development panel that still contains the broken link to Fisheye/Crucible data.



h3. Expected Results
Removing a repository from Fisheye would also remove commit data from the Development Panel of linked JIRA issues.


h3. Actual Results
The commits remain in the Development Panel. If you click the link to view more information about the commit you are presented with an error:
"You don't have access to view all related commits. Please contact your administrator."
 
h3. Notes

None of the following appears to have an effect on the behavior:

Removing and adding application links
Restarting JIRA and Fisheye
Refreshing the repo cache in JIRA > Applications > Fisheye
Flushing the cache in JIRA > Applications > Fisheye
Refreshing "Connected developer tools" in JIRA > Projects > MyProject > Developer Tools




h3.Workaround

No workaround found.
fields.summary: Development Panel doesn't remove links to deleted repositories/reviews in Fisheye or Crucible.

fields.description:
Dear Atlassian,

Someone connect same repositories in our Fisheye server.

This should be prevented, because when creating a review via smart commit, Crucible assigns the review to either repository instance at random.

Fisheye should offer a restriction or a message to remind user have been have a same repository in the Fisheye.

Thank you & Bother you,
Vic
